question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, President Joe Biden has not indicated any intention to withdraw from the 2024 presidential race. He has publicly expressed his commitment to seeking re-election and has been actively involved in campaign activities. Additionally, there have been no significant health concerns or unprecedented political developments that suggest he might change his decision. While factors such as age and approval ratings can influence a president's decision to run for another term, there is currently no concrete evidence to suggest that Biden will make a definitive announcement to not seek re-nomination before July 15, 2024.

question.title: If Joe Biden announces he will not accept the Democratic nomination, will Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Joe Biden announces before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President. This announcement must be definitive, unambiguous, and made publicly by Biden or his campaign, leaving no possibility of him accepting the nomination for the 2024 election.

Given this, will Kamala Harris's Electoral College probability in Nate Silver's model be greater than 46.6% on Friday, August 9th, at 8:40 PM? Resolves YES if it is >46.6% at that time, and NO otherwise.

This analysis considers the impact of Biden's decision on Harris's perceived chances in the model, as tracked on Nate Silver's platform.

metadata.chain_of_thought: If Joe Biden definitively announces he will not accept the Democratic nomination before July 15, 2024, Kamala Harris is the likely successor as the Democratic presidential nominee. Nate Silver's model would take into account factors such as Harris's political experience, incumbency advantages as Vice President, party support, and current polling data. Assuming that the Democratic Party remains unified behind Harris and there are no significant negative developments affecting her campaign, her chances in the Electoral College would likely be similar to or slightly less than Biden's. Given that the threshold for resolving YES is a probability greater than 46.6%, and considering the strength of the Democratic base and typical Electoral College distributions, it is reasonable to estimate that Harris's Electoral College probability would exceed this threshold by August 9th.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President? (b) Will Kamala's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
(a) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President? This resolves as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President in the 2024 election cycle. If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

(b) Will Kamala's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model? Resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday August 9th at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise. Link: https://www.natesilver.net/p/nate-silver-2024-president-election-polls-model

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To determine the probability that both events (a) and (b) will occur, we assess each component separately based on available information up to October 2023.

(a) **Joe Biden Not Seeking Re-election Before July 15, 2024:** As of the latest information, President Joe Biden has indicated intentions to seek a second term in the 2024 election cycle. Historically, incumbent presidents typically announce their re-election bids well in advance to manage campaign logistics and fundraising. An announcement withdrawing from the race before July 15, 2024, would be unprecedented at this stage, especially considering the relatively short time frame before the resolution date.

(b) **Kamala Harris's Odds Increasing in Nate Silver's Model:** Kamala Harris has not been a primary contender for the Democratic presidential nomination as of the latest data. Nate Silver's models are based on current polling and election data, which, up to October 2023, do not indicate a significant surge in her candidacy's viability. Unless there are unforeseen developments or shifts in the political landscape between July and August 2024, it's unlikely that her odds would see a substantial increase in such a short period.

Given that both conditions are independently unlikely and even less probable to occur simultaneously, the combined probability is very low.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, there has been no legal determination that Donald Trump engaged in insurrection or rebellion that would invoke Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. Removing or blocking a candidate from a primary election ballot under this amendment requires a clear legal finding that the individual has participated in such activities. While Trump has faced various legal challenges and investigations, none have resulted in a verdict that satisfies the criteria set by Section 3. Additionally, implementing such a removal would likely require a combination of state-level actions and federal court rulings, both of which have not occurred to date. Given the high threshold for disqualification and the absence of current legal actions meeting these standards, it is unlikely that Trump will be removed or blocked from any primary election ballot for a federal office by July 15, 2024.

question.title: Given Donald Trump is removed or blocked from a primary ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, will he be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, as of July 15, 2024. This removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports, and is not reversed by that date.

Then, is it true that Donald Trump will be selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? The resolution is based on the decision made by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, regardless of the eventual outcome of the 2024 US election.

metadata.chain_of_thought: If Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of every U.S. state under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, this would effectively eliminate his ability to gather delegates through the primary process. The Republican National Convention relies on delegates who are typically pledged to vote for specific candidates based on primary and caucus results. With Trump unable to appear on any primary ballots, he would not have the necessary delegate support to secure the nomination. Additionally, the Republican Party leadership and delegates are likely to support an alternative candidate who remains eligible and can legitimately compete in the general election. Therefore, it is highly unlikely that Trump would be selected as the Republican nominee under these circumstances.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Donald Trump is removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, and (2) Donald Trump is the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if both of the following conditions are met:

1. As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. Note that the question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

2. Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. It is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.

The question will resolve as "No" if either or both of these conditions are not met.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, there have been ongoing discussions and legal debates regarding the application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to disqualify Donald Trump from holding federal office due to actions related to the January 6th events. However, no court has definitively ruled to remove or block him from primary election ballots across any U.S. state by the specified date of July 15, 2024. Additionally, Trump maintains significant influence and support within the Republican Party, making it plausible for him to secure the Republican nomination for the 2024 Presidential Election. The combination of being both removed from ballots and simultaneously becoming the party's nominee presents a complex and unlikely scenario, given the legal, political, and procedural hurdles involved.

question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: Donald Trump Jr. has not formally announced a candidacy for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and historically, his father, Donald Trump, has been the more prominent figure within the Republican Party. The Republican National Convention typically nominates candidates with significant political experience and established support within the party, neither of which strongly aligns with Donald Trump Jr.'s current political trajectory. Additionally, other potential candidates like Ron DeSantis and Nikki Haley have garnered more attention and support as potential nominees. Given these factors, it is unlikely that Donald Trump Jr. will secure the Republican nomination by August 1, 2024.

question.title: Conditional on Donald Trump Jr. being the Republican nominee, will Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question resolves as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. If this condition is met, then the question resolves as **No** for Asa Hutchinson, as only one candidate can be the nominee.

Resolution criteria for the condition: Donald Trump Jr. must be selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention as the nominee.
Resolution criteria for the outcome: Asa Hutchinson must be selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention as the nominee, which is impossible if Donald Trump Jr. is the nominee. Therefore, if Donald Trump Jr. is the nominee, this resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: In the United States political system, each major party selects only one nominee to represent them in the presidential election through their respective conventions. If Donald Trump Jr. is confirmed as the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, he would be the sole representative of the Republican Party for that election cycle. Since a party cannot have multiple nominees simultaneously, Asa Hutchinson would not be able to also serve as the Republican nominee under these circumstances. Therefore, the probability that Asa Hutchinson is the Republican nominee, given that Donald Trump Jr. is already the nominee, is virtually nonexistent.

question.title: Will both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson are selected by the Republican National Convention as nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other combinations of candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: The Republican Party traditionally nominates a single candidate for the presidential election through the Republican National Convention. It is unprecedented for the party to endorse two candidates simultaneously. Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson have distinct political profiles and support bases, making a joint nomination highly improbable. Additionally, there have been no indications or movements within the party suggesting a willingness to pursue dual nominations. Given the established norms and the lack of supporting evidence, the likelihood of both individuals being selected as Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election is extremely low.

question.title: Will Joe Biden die before Saturday?
question.body:
Resolves YES if there is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th. 

Otherwise, resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Joe Biden is the sitting President of the United States and is in generally stable health. While he is one of the older presidents, there have been no public indications or official announcements suggesting any imminent health issues that would lead to his passing. Additionally, predicting the death of an individual, especially a public figure, within a specific short timeframe lacks sufficient evidence and is highly speculative. Therefore, it is extremely unlikely that there will be an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before the market close on Friday, July 26th, 2024.

question.title: If Joe Biden dies before Saturday, will he remain President through the end of July 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Joe Biden dies before Saturday, with an official announcement of his death made before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th. 

Resolution criteria for the condition: Resolves YES if there is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th. Otherwise, resolves NO.

Resolution criteria for the outcome: Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then. Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment (i.e., making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

If the condition is not met, resolves N/A.

metadata.chain_of_thought: If Joe Biden dies before Saturday, July 26th, the Vice President would immediately assume the role of President as per the U.S. Constitution. This transition means Joe Biden would no longer serve as President through the end of July 2024. The resolution criteria specify that temporary transfers under the 25th Amendment do not result in a 'YES' resolution, as the Acting President is distinct from the President under the Constitution.

question.title: Will Joe Biden die before Saturday and remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if both of the following occur: (a) There is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, and (b) Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET).

Resolves NO if either Joe Biden does not die before the specified time or he does not remain President through the specified time. Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment does not affect the resolution regarding his presidency.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The resolution requires two conditions to be met simultaneously: (a) an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before the end of Friday, July 26th, 2024, and (b) Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024. These two conditions are mutually exclusive. If Biden dies before July 26th, he cannot remain President through the end of July as the Vice President would assume the presidency. Consequently, the probability of both conditions being satisfied at the same time is effectively zero.

question.title: Will the USA win more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if the United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: Historically, the United States has been a dominant force in the Olympic Games, often securing a high number of both Gold and Silver medals. In the 2016 Rio Olympics, the USA won more Gold medals (46) than Silver (37). However, in the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, this trend reversed slightly, with the USA winning 39 Gold and 41 Silver medals. This fluctuation suggests that while the USA is consistently among the top performers, the margin between Gold and Silver medals can vary based on numerous factors such as athlete performance, competition level, and emerging talents in specific sports. Given the relatively recent shifts and the inherent unpredictability of athletic competitions, it is reasonable to assign a balanced probability to the USA winning more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

question.title: Given the USA wins more Gold than Silver medals, will they top the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: The United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics. Then, will the USA be the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics?

Resolution criteria for the condition: Resolves YES if the USA wins more Gold than Silver medals.
Resolution criteria for the outcome: Resolves positively if the USA is the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. Resolves ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. Resolves negatively if any team achieves a higher or equal ranking to the US team. The ranking is determined by the number of Gold, Silver, and Bronze medals in that order.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: Historically, the United States has been a dominant force in the Olympic Games, consistently ranking at the top of the medal table, particularly in terms of gold medals. Winning more gold than silver medals indicates a strong performance across multiple sports. However, the competition from other leading countries such as China, Russia, and various European nations cannot be overlooked, as their performances can vary significantly from one Olympics to another. Additionally, factors like athlete preparation, potential injuries, and geopolitical situations can influence the final medal standings. Given that the USA winning more gold than silver suggests a high level of performance, it increases the likelihood of them topping the medal table, but the presence of strong competitors means there is still some uncertainty.

question.title: Will the USA win more Gold than Silver medals and also top the Olympic Medal Table at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if both of the following conditions are met: (a) The United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics. (b) The United States Olympic Team is the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. The ranking is determined by the number of Gold medals, followed by Silver, and then Bronze medals. The question resolves ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It resolves negatively if either condition (a) or (b) is not met.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To estimate the probability that the USA will win more Gold than Silver medals and top the Olympic Medal Table at the Paris 2024 Olympics, several factors need to be considered:

1. **Historical Performance**: The United States has a strong track record in the Olympics, consistently securing the highest number of medals, particularly Gold medals. This historical dominance suggests a solid foundation for continued success.

2. **Team Composition and Preparation**: The depth and breadth of the US Olympic team across various sports, along with the emergence of new talents, play a crucial role. Effective preparation and training leading up to the Olympics can enhance the team's performance.

3. **Competition**: Other leading nations, notably China and European countries, are also investing heavily in their Olympic programs. The level of competition from these countries can impact the USA's ability to secure the top spot and more Gold medals.

4. **Host Nation Advantage**: While Paris is a significant and historic location, it does not present the same home advantage that the USA might have had in previous Olympics held in the US. This could slightly level the playing field for other nations.

5. **Recent Performance Trends**: Assessing the performance of the US team in recent international competitions, World Championships, and other preparatory events leading up to Paris 2024 can provide insights into their potential success.

6. **External Factors**: Unforeseen circumstances such as injuries, economic factors, or geopolitical issues could influence the outcomes of the competitions.

Considering these factors, the USA has a strong likelihood of performing exceptionally well, but the exact probability depends on the dynamic interplay of these elements leading up to and during the Olympics.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The likelihood of at least 20 House or Senate Democrats signing a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate President Joe Biden early depends on several factors. Firstly, there is evidence of internal dissent within the Democratic caucus, as indicated by efforts to organize opposition and the circulation of a drafted letter by Rep. Jared Huffman. This suggests that there is some momentum behind the initiative. Additionally, political strategy plays a role; Democrats may seek to demonstrate unity or address genuine concerns about the nomination process to maintain public support and party cohesion. However, reaching the threshold of 20 signatures might be challenging due to potential loyalty to party leadership, the desire to present a united front, and varying personal or political calculations among members. Without specific data on the number of active opponents and their willingness to publicly dissent, it's difficult to ascertain the exact likelihood.

question.title: Will at least 5 countries win their first Olympic medal at the 2024 Games?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic medal at the Paris Olympics, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions).

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: Historically, the number of countries winning their first-ever Olympic medals has been declining as more nations develop competitive sports programs. In recent Summer Olympics, typically between one to four countries achieve their inaugural medals. While it's possible for new nations to emerge and secure their first medals, reaching a threshold of five or more would be uncommon based on past trends. Additionally, the increasing competitiveness of the Games makes it more challenging for new countries to break through. Considering these factors, it is somewhat unlikely that at least five countries will win their first Olympic medal at the 2024 Paris Games.

The resolution criteria for the condition is that 5 or more countries must win their first-ever Olympic medal. The resolution criteria for the outcome is that 5 or more countries must win their first-ever Olympic gold medal.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Winning a first-ever Olympic medal is a significant achievement for any country, but securing a gold medal is even more challenging due to the high level of global competition. Historically, countries winning their debut medals are more likely to receive silver or bronze rather than gold, as gold medals typically require exceptional performance and resources. Given that at least 5 countries are winning their first Olympic medals at the 2024 Games, it would be less common for all or most of these to achieve their first gold medal. Factors such as the country's investment in sports, existing athletic infrastructure, and experience in international competitions play crucial roles in determining the likelihood of winning gold. Considering these aspects, the probability that at least 5 of these countries will win their debut gold medals is relatively low.

question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if both of the following occur at the Paris Olympics: (a) 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic medal, and (b) 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic gold medal, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions).

Most nations that compete in the Olympics have secured at least one medal over the years, and first gold medals are even less common. In recent Olympic Games, fewer than five countries typically achieve their first medal, and even fewer reach the gold podium. Additionally, the emergence of new nations capable of winning medals has been infrequent. Given these trends, the likelihood that at least five countries will win their first Olympic medal and at least five will win their first gold medal at the 2024 Paris Olympics is low.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of the current reports, two safe-seat Democratic House Members have publicly urged President Biden to step down, and two endangered Democrats have expressed skepticism about his chances in the November elections. Additionally, there are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats, but these efforts involve unnamed individuals behind the scenes. For the market to resolve YES, at least five named Democratic US House Members or US Senators must collectively ask Biden to end his campaign publicly by July 20th. Given that only four named members have publicly indicated doubts and the remaining efforts involve unnamed individuals, it is unlikely that a named group of five will formally pressure Biden to drop out by the specified deadline.

question.body:
(a) A group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators must work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time). This could be by signing a letter or another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person. All five individuals must be part of the same group message. Reports of unnamed democrats will not satisfy this criterion unless at least 5 qualifying names are made public before the end date. If these criteria are not met, this condition resolves NO.

(b) Joe Biden or his campaign must make a definitive, public, official announcement before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, stating that he will not seek and will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the nomination. If such a statement is not made prior to the deadline, this condition resolves NO.

This combined question resolves YES if both (a) and (b) occur as described above.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of the latest information available up to October 2023, President Joe Biden has not indicated any intention to drop out of the 2024 presidential race. Historically, incumbent presidents rarely face significant pressure from their own party's members to withdraw from re-election bids unless there are major scandals or shifts in public opinion, neither of which are currently evident for Biden. Additionally, organizing a group of at least five named Democratic House Members or Senators to publicly pressure the president to withdraw is logistically challenging and unprecedented in modern U.S. politics. On the other hand, for Biden to announce by July 15, 2024, that he will not seek the Democratic nomination would require a substantial and swift change in circumstances or personal decision, neither of which has been indicated. Given these factors, the likelihood of both conditions (a) and (b) occurring as described is very low.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

question.title: Will Vivek Ramaswamy be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:

All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: Vivek Ramaswamy has emerged as a notable contender in the Republican primary for the 2024 US Presidential Election, bringing a background in entrepreneurship and a platform focused on issues like economic reform and combating 'woke' culture. However, he faces significant challenges in securing the Republican nomination. Prominent figures such as former President Donald Trump and Florida Governor Ron DeSantis currently hold substantial support within the party, both in terms of voter base and organizational backing. Trump's enduring influence and proven fundraising capabilities, coupled with DeSantis's appeal to a broad spectrum of Republican voters, present formidable obstacles for Ramaswamy. Additionally, Ramaswamy is relatively new to the political arena compared to his rivals, which may impact his ability to garner widespread recognition and support quickly enough to secure the nomination. While his unique positioning and outsider status could attract voters seeking alternatives to traditional candidates, overcoming the established momentum of his competitors will require significant effort and favorable developments in the primaries.

question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of early 2024, President Joe Biden has not publicly indicated any intention to step down or decline the Democratic nomination for the 2024 Presidential election. Historically, incumbent presidents seeking re-election tend to run unless there are significant personal, health, or political reasons prompting them to retire. While Biden's age (he turned 81 in November 2023) is a factor that could influence such a decision, there has been no definitive indication from him or his campaign that he plans to withdraw from the race. Additionally, the Democratic Party typically rallies behind incumbent candidates unless there is a strong push for an alternative. Given the lack of concrete signals pointing towards a withdrawal and the ongoing campaign activities, it seems relatively unlikely that Biden will announce he will not seek the nomination before July 15, 2024.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Joe Biden announces before July 15, 2024, he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President, and (b) the Republican Party retains Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election?
question.body:
(a) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle. If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

(b) Will the Republican Party retain Ohio's 6th congressional district (previously held by Bill Johnson) in the 2024 special election?

This question will resolve as Yes if credible sources report that a person representing the Republican Party has won the special election for OH's 6th district. If popular sources are in disagreement, an Ohio State source or statement will be used. If no election is held before January 1, 2025, the question is annulled.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To estimate the probability that both events (a) and (b) occur, we need to assess each event individually and then consider their combined likelihood.

**Event (a): Joe Biden announces before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President.**

As of the knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Joe Biden has not made any public statements indicating his intention to forgo seeking a second term. Historically, incumbent presidents seeking re-election often announce their campaigns by the convention season, but official announcements can vary. Given Biden's age and some speculation about his retirement, there is a non-negligible chance he might choose not to run again. However, without a definitive statement, the probability remains uncertain but seemingly less than even.

**Event (b): The Republican Party retains Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election.**

Ohio's 6th congressional district has been a competitive area with a history of fluctuating political control. Special elections can be influenced by current political climates, candidate quality, and national trends. Assuming no significant shifts in voter sentiment and based on historical data, the Republican Party might have a slight advantage in retaining the seat, but it's far from certain.

**Combined Probability:**

Assuming the two events are independent:

- Let’s estimate a 30% (0.3) probability for Event (a) occurring.
- Let’s estimate a 55% (0.55) probability for Event (b) occurring.

The combined probability of both events occurring is 0.3 * 0.55 = 0.165.

question.title: Will Israel carry out a deadly attack within Iran before May 1, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves **Yes** if, following the date of this question's publication and before May 1, 2024, credible reports indicate that an attack attributed to Israel and occurring within Iran's borders has led to the death of at least five individuals.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there has been ongoing tension between Israel and Iran, primarily due to Iran's nuclear program and its support for proxy groups in the region. Both countries have a history of hostile actions and retaliations, but direct military engagements have been limited. Israel has conducted airstrikes in Syria against Iranian targets in the past to prevent the establishment of a permanent military presence by Iran near its borders. However, a large-scale deadly attack within Iran would represent a significant escalation with substantial geopolitical repercussions. Such an action would likely provoke international condemnation and could destabilize the region further. Additionally, Israel typically engages in preemptive strikes only when it perceives an immediate and existential threat. Given the short time frame until May 1, 2024, and assuming no significant changes in the geopolitical landscape after October 2023, the likelihood of Israel carrying out a deadly attack within Iran in this period appears low.

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, Joe Biden is serving as the President of the United States with his term expected to continue until January 2025. There have been no indications or credible reports suggesting that President Biden plans to resign, has health issues that would necessitate stepping down, or faces imminent political challenges that could remove him from office before the end of his term. Historically, U.S. presidents typically serve their full terms unless unforeseen circumstances arise. While President Biden is the oldest person to hold the office, there have been no substantial signs of instability or factors that would likely cause him to leave the presidency by the end of July 2024. Therefore, based on the available information up to October 2023, it is highly probable that President Biden will remain in office through the specified period.

question.title: If Biden remains President through July 2024, will Trump be removed from any state ballot under 14th Amendment Section 3?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Joe Biden remains the President of the United States through the end of July 2024. This means he does not resign, die, or otherwise cease to be President before then. Temporary transfer of power under the 25th Amendment, making his VP the Acting President, does not affect this status.

Then, is it true that Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment? This resolves as "Yes" if, on July 15, 2024, Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, as confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. The resolution is "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024. Note: The question strictly pertains to the status as of July 15, 2024, and does not consider legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals after this date. If Trump is removed or blocked and then reinstated such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in September 2023, there have been discussions about the potential application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to disqualify Donald Trump from holding federal office due to allegations related to the events of January 6, 2021. However, invoking this section requires a clear legal determination that an individual engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States. This process would likely involve lengthy legal battles, including court rulings and potential legislative actions to enforce such disqualifications. Historically, Section 3 has been rarely used, and its application is subject to complex legal interpretations. Additionally, there has been no definitive action taken by state governments or courts to remove Trump from ballots under this provision as of September 2023. Given these factors, while it's not impossible for Trump to be disqualified under Section 3 by July 2024, significant legal and political hurdles make it unlikely.

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024, and will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if both of the following conditions are met:

1. Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET). This resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then. Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment (i.e., making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution).

2. On July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024. Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

Both conditions must be met for this question to resolve as "Yes".

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, President Joe Biden has maintained a stable position with no immediate indications of resignation, health issues, or political pressures that would lead to him leaving office before the end of July 2024. The U.S. has established protocols for presidential succession, and any temporary transfer of power under the 25th Amendment would not alter the constitutional designation of the sitting president. 

Regarding Donald Trump being removed or blocked from primary election ballots under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, this scenario presents significant legal and procedural challenges. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment addresses disqualification from holding office for individuals who engaged in insurrection or rebellion, but its application requires clear legal definitions and judicial proceedings. As of the current knowledge cutoff, there have been no definitive legal actions or court rulings that would support such a removal. Additionally, the political polarization in the U.S. makes the enforcement of this section highly contentious and unlikely without substantial legal precedents.

Considering both conditions must be met for a "Yes" resolution, the probability that President Biden remains in office through July 2024 is high, while the likelihood of successfully removing Trump from primary ballots under the specified constitutional provision is low.

Suppose the following is true: OpenAI publishes a *public* report with results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models by June 30, 2024.
